content:
Yep. Reiterating my core point:

The PeerDAS timeline cannot be compromised due to fragmentation of focus, testing resources, and tail risk.

author: alexsharp12
content: Object format allows you to specify the mapping between storage and VM memory prior to the execution of the code (data sections). Without object format, data has to be loaded explicitely into the VM memory by such instructions as `SLOAD`, etc. If Ethereum were to fix the incomprehensive state problem, it would need to migrate to linear (from hashtable) model of storage, and this requires the structure and semantics that object format brings. But I doubt very much this will ever happen. Against, because there is no strategy to make this happen

content: It is incorrect to think that Solana has more TPS only because it allows more TPS. It has a different (I would say more modern) design of the state and VM. If one takes Solana code, removes the bits that pump 1 block every 400ms, and instead makes it do 1 block every 12 seconds, and changes consensus, it would still be a very interesting chain. The most interesting feature in such mini-Solana (as I call it now) is that the history of the state (and retracing) is not required to figure out what is currently present in the state. So the history becomes.... just history, for auditing purposes and such, as it should be

i agree with the point, though want to point out that the value of ETH still participates in network security broadly and scales the magnitude of rewards the network can pay out, which also has impacts on geographic decentralisation and other nice things. there really is a virtuous circle between many of the cypherpunk use cases people care about (e.g., privacy, which is expensive onchain; hardness, or the ability to have trust-minimised access to your assets over long periods of time) and much more pragmatic concerns such as TPS/gas throughput or ETH/network value

author: notnotstorm
content:
an incomplete list of problems that appear with lower ETH price:
- becomes easier for a single entity to acquire a large portion of the ETH supply
- less ability to punish misbehaving validators
- more dependence on centralized fiat currency, both onchain and offchain
- less support for validators to remain independent and invest in network+physical security
- less ability for the EF and other ETH holders to fund devs/researchers/ops/publicgoods and buy irl resources to support the network

increasing ethereum's scaling and increasing the price of ETH both increase ethereum's power to project its values onto the world

building a network that merely follows every cypherpunk principle will not make the world a better place if barely anyone uses it. additional ingredients are needed 

more scaling = more ppl can use ethereum. more ETH price = more ability to secure a large portion of the world's financial system. these together = more power for ethereum to project its values onto the world. if you truly care about building The Future of Finance then it doesn't make sense to be ok with hobbling ethereum's power by ignoring these important ingredients

author: sky.cactus
content:
I think it is important for framing discussions.  Many people say ETH price must be high for Ethereum to be secure, but the more correct statement is that stake must not be consolidoted for Ethereum to be secure.  I believe we have been seeing stake consolidate over time, and Bitcoin hashpower is almost completely consolidated at this point.  Saying they are secure because they have high market cap is wrong in some scenarios (consolidated stake/hash power) and leads people to an incorrect sense of security.

Also, recognizing what your actual requirements are rather than proxy requirements is the first step to looking for alternative solutions.  As long as the solution to securing Ethereum is "price must be high" we won't look for other ways to prevent stakers consolidation.

I'm not saying I have solutions to these problems, but anytime you do mechanism design or attack design the first step is to understand the *real* constraints on the system, not the second order constraints.
